item.title: Tiny deer and rising seas: How climate change is testing the Endangered Species Act
item.description: In the audio of this episode, we incorrectly stated that Valerie Preziosi is the founder of Key Deer Alliance. In fact, she is the founder and director of the organization Save Our Key Deer.

item.title: Jonathan Majors' trial for assault and harassment charges rescheduled again
item.description: A previous version of this story said the incident that led to Jonathan Majors' arrest occurred in March 2022. In fact, it occurred in 2023.

item.title: How IBM's gamble ushered in the computer age
item.description: In a previous version of this episode, we stated that Thomas Watson Jr. fought on the side of the United States in World War II while IBM, under his father's leadership, was doing business with the Nazi regime. As a World War II pilot, Watson didn't fight in combat missions, but some of his missions did take him through combat zones where he faced enemy fire. And while IBM did sell technology to the Nazi government in the years leading up to the U.S.'s involvement in World War II, by the time the U.S. entered the war and Watson was serving in the war, the German government had seized the assets of American companies, curtailing IBM's control over its German operations.

item.title: An off-duty pilot attempted to shut off the engines in flight, Alaska Airlines says
item.description: In an earlier version of this story, we incorrectly reported that flight attendants were permitted to occupy a jump seat in the flight deck.

item.title: Freed Israeli hostage: Hamas kidnapping was 'hell'
item.description: NPR has updated this story to reflect a more accurate translation of Yocheved Lifshitz's statement describing her time in captivity as "hell," rather than a "nightmare" as previously published.

item.title: Palestinians brace for more violence after reprisal attacks in the West Bank
item.description: An earlier version of this story said a lawyer had told NPR of shootings of Palestinians. In fact the lawyer told of shootings of Israelis.

item.title: Britney Spears memoir reaches bestseller status a week before it hits shelves
item.description: An earlier version of this story reference Spears' growing up in Mississippi. She was born there but grew up in Louisiana. The reference has been removed.

item.title: Using AI, cartoonist Amy Kurzweil connects with deceased grandfather in 'Artificial'
item.description: An earlier version of this story incorrectly stated that Kristen Radtke was a cartoonist for the New Yorker. She's a graphic memoirist and the creative director of The Verge.

item.title: Hundreds killed in explosion at a crowded Gaza hospital
item.description: An earlier version of this story misstated the name of the hospital as the Ali Ahli Baptist Hospital in Gaza. The correct name is the Al Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza.

item.title: Bike riding in middle school may boost mental health, study finds
item.description: An earlier version of this story referred to Dr. Allan Reiss as a neuropsychologist. He is in fact a neuropsychiatrist.

item.title: Retirement benefits are one of the hang-ups in UAW negotiations
item.description: This story incorrectly stated that at one point, GM had 10 retired workers for every active one. In its 2005 annual report, GM reported 3.2 retirees and surviving spouses for every active employee in the U.S.

item.title: 'Total War: Pharaoh' and 'Star Trek: Infinite': boldly going where we've been before
item.description: An earlier version of this story misstated the name of the fictional Star Trek species Cardassian as Cassardian.

item.title: After historic strike, Kaiser Permanente workers win 21% raise over 4 years
item.description: An earlier version of this story misspelled the last name of SEIU United Healthcare Workers President Dave Regan as Reagan.

item.title: Daniel Mason on his novel, 'North Woods'
item.description: An earlier headline misspelled the last name of Daniel Mason as Masoon.

item.title: Israel Issues Evacuation Order For Gaza, Scalise Drops Out, Elijah McClain Verdict
item.description: An earlier headline misspelled the last name of Elijah McClain as McCain.

item.title: Gazans flee their homes after an Israeli evacuation order but have few places to go
item.description: A previous version of this story said Israel ordered Gazans to leave their homes within 24 hours. In fact, Israel did not give a specific deadline for Gazans to evacuate. U.N. officials in Gaza say Israel told them to evacuate within 24 hours.

item.title: 'Irth' hospital review app aims to take the bias out of giving birth
item.description: In a previous version of this story, we included an incorrectly transcribed quote from Kimberly Seals Allers stating that Cedars-Sinai hospital in Los Angeles had a high rate of Black maternal mortality. In fact, the quote did not mention Cedar-Sinai's rate; it refers to a single high-profile Black maternal death. A previous version also incorrectly stated that Seals Allers was from Harlem, N.Y. She is from Queens.

item.title: Scalise drops out of race for speaker of the House, leaving Congress in limbo
item.description: An earlier version of this story mistakenly said Rep. Steve Scalise defeated Rep. Jim Jordan in a 110-99 vote for House Republicans' speaker nominee. In fact, the vote was 113-99.

item.title: The sexual assault victims suing Uber notch a legal victory in their long battle
item.description: A previous version of this story incorrectly cited Uber's data on sexual assault and rape as "incidents," rather than "reported incidents."

item.title: Migrant mothers arriving in New York find support, hope — and lots of challenges
item.description: A previous version of the captions in this story referred to a maternity care unit at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York City. The hotel hosts a medical clinic.

item.title: Writers union votes to ratify contract, ending one of Hollywood's longest strikes
item.description: Many NPR newsroom staff are members of SAG-AFTRA but are not part of the bargaining unit that is striking.

item.title: One sister survived cancer. Five years later, the other one is still processing it
item.description: A previous version of the broadcast story stated that next month Kristin Long at Boston University will host a convention for siblings like Kayla and Ella in Chicago. The convention is focused on how to support siblings like them.

item.title: He watched his family get taken by Hamas fighters. Now he wants Israel to fight back
item.description: A previous version of this story misspelled Yosi Shnaider as Yosi Shnaidel.

item.title: An 'anti-World's Fair' makes its case: give land back to Native Americans
item.description: Previous versions of this story incorrectly stated the city that gave back an island as Eureka, Ore. It is Eureka, Calif.

item.title: Israel, even with superior intelligence abilities, fails to anticipate Hamas attack
item.description: Earlier digital and audio versions characterized the guest as a top adviser to a former Israeli prime minister. Daniel Levy was an adviser in the government of former Prime Minister Ehud Barak.

item.title: Villano Antillano: Tiny Desk Concert
item.description: This page originally credited Emilio Mendez as the keyboardist in this Tiny Desk performance. It was Barba Blanca.

item.title: New technology uses good old-fashioned wind to power giant cargo vessels
item.description: Previous audio and digital versions of this story said the IMO's goal was to cut the shipping industry's greenhouse gas emissions at least in half by 2050. In fact, a revised goal put out earlier this year calls for the industry to reach net zero by mid-century.

item.title: Biden's dog Commander has left the White House
item.description: A previous version of this story incorrectly said the most recent biting incident was on Monday evening. In fact, it was the previous Monday, Sept. 25.

item.title: Poet Safiya Sinclair reflects on her Rastafari roots and how she cut herself free
item.description: An earlier version of this story incorrectly quoted Sinclair as saying she realized that poetry could "alkalize" the hurt she was feeling. Sinclair said she realized that poetry cold alchemize that hurt.

item.title: Los Angeles is using AI to predict who might become homeless and help before they do
item.description: Previous photo captions in this story misspelled Valarie Zayas' name as Valaria.

item.title: Workers at Kaiser Permanente are poised to go out on strike
item.description: A previous version of the headline misspelled Kaiser Permanente as Kaiser Permanent.

item.title: Any job can be a climate solutions job: Ask this teacher, electrician or beauty CEO
item.description: An earlier version of this story referred to the hair line Braidbetter as Bright Better.

item.title: Patrick Stewart says his time on 'Star Trek' felt like a ministry
item.description: This story has been updated to replace a photo of Patrick Stewart in costume as Jean Luc Picard that had been reversed by the agency that provided it.

item.title: How did we come to live extremely online? Mommy bloggers, says one writer
item.description: An earlier version of this story incorrectly used "kid" instead of "kids" in a quote from Taylor Lorenz

item.title: These 5 big purchases can save energy — and money — at home
item.description:
A version of this story incorrectly labeled an image of an electric glass cooktop as an induction stove. The image has been removed and updated.
A previous version of this story and its headline incorrectly stated there were six recommendations listed in the story. There are actually five suggestions in the story.

item.title: 'Carterland' puts a positive spin on an oft-disparaged presidency
item.description: An earlier version of this story incorrectly said that President Jimmy Carter appointed Ben Bernanke to head the Federal Reserve. In fact, he appointed Paul Volcker.

item.title: Donald Trump's business fraud trial wraps up day one in New York
item.description: A previous version of this story incorrectly included Ivanka Trump as among those who are accused of fraud. She is not.

item.title: Poland's dangerous eastern border takes center stage in upcoming elections
item.description: A previous version of this story misspelled Bialowieza, the name of a forest and town in Poland.

item.title: Who's in the Army now? A pitch switch aims to get more military recruits
item.description: An earlier version of this story misspelled the first name of Lt. Col. Khrysten Grace as Kristen.

item.title: Anger grows over Ukraine's largest Orthodox church, aligned with Moscow despite war
item.description: In a previous version of this story, we misidentified an image of a monastery in Kyiv and also inaccurately described the location of a protest rally in the Ukrainian capital.

item.title: The career and legacy of Sen. Dianne Feinstein
item.description: A previous headline misspelled Sen. Dianne Feinstein's first name as Diane.

item.title: Trump's N.Y. business empire is 'greatly at risk' from judge's fraud ruling
item.description: A previous version of this story misspelled John Coffee's surname as Coffey.

item.title: The White House chief of staff says it's on House Republicans to avert a shutdown
item.description: A previous version of this story incorrectly said that a government shutdown — rather than proposed budget cuts from House Republicans — would hurt seniors who rely on Meals on Wheels and families with kids in Head Start programs.

item.title: What a government shutdown would mean for the U.S. military — and national security
item.description: This story has been updated to reflect that Coast Guard members did not get paid during the 2018-2019 government shutdown.

item.title: Hollywood writers return to work, after a nearly five month strike
item.description: In the audio of this story, as in a previous web version, we incorrectly identify David Goodman as the current president of the WGA West. Goodman is a past president of the WGA West and current co-chair of the WGA's negotiating committee.

item.title: House GOP rebels recall a distant era when dissidents rose up against 'Czar Cannon'
item.description: A previous photo caption incorrectly said Republican Rep. Joseph Cannon of Illinois was ousted as House speaker after a revolt in 2010. In fact, he lost much of his power after a revolt in 1910 but remained speaker until the following year.

item.title: What's Making Us Happy: A guide to your weekend viewing and reading
item.description: A previous version of this story incorrectly said that in Dreaming Whilst Black, Adjani Salmon plays Kwabena, an aspiring filmmaker living with his brother and sister-in-law. In fact, Kwabena lives with his cousin and cousin's wife.

item.title: The WNBA's coming out story; plus, the dangers of sports betting
item.description: An earlier version of this story suggested that New York has banned advertising of sports betting on college campuses. The New York State Gaming Commission has prohibited ads sent to people under the age of 21.

item.title: 'Sex Education' teaches valuable lessons in empathy
item.description: A previous version of this episode incorrectly said that in Dreaming Whilst Black, Adjani Salmon plays Kwabena, an aspiring filmmaker living with his brother and sister-in-law. In fact, Kwabena lives with his cousin and cousin's wife.

item.title: Remembering Olympic gold medalist Florence 'Flo-Jo' Griffith Joyner
item.description: A previous photo caption incorrectly said Florence Griffith Joyner won a silver medal for the 200 meters at the 1988 Summer Olympic Games. In fact, she won silver for the 4x400 meter relay.

item.title: As Ukraine's war drags on and a D.C. shutdown looms, Zelenskyy makes his case for aid
item.description: The original version of this story correctly said that 29 Republican lawmakers signed a letter to the White House's budget director announcing they would oppose President Biden's $24 billion funding request. At one point, the story was mistakenly changed to say the letter had 28 signatories. The original figure of 29 signatories has been restored.

item.title: Gen. C.Q. Brown confirmed as top military officer despite Tuberville's roadblock
item.description: A previous version of this story said Gen. Eric Smith was confirmed in the Senate by an 83-11 vote. The nomination was approved 96-0.

item.title: GOP presidential hopeful Doug Burgum says he'd leave abortion laws up to the states
item.description: In an earlier version of the transcript, a question asked by Asma Khalid was incorrectly attributed to Susan Davis.

item.title: A Danish artist has been ordered to repay a museum after delivering blank canvases
item.description: An earlier version of this story listed an incorrect currency when describing a loan provided by the Kunsten Museum of Modern Art to artist Jens Haaning. The loan was provided in Danish krone.

item.title: Historian Simon Schama's new book traces the roots of today's distrust of vaccines
item.description: A previous headline misspelled Simon Schama's last name as Schema.

item.title: Ohio's Hopewell Ceremonial Earthworks are now a UNESCO World Heritage site
item.description: A previous version of the story said Jennifer Aultman is director of historic sites and museums at Ohio History Connection. She is the organization's chief historic sites officer.

item.title: Up First briefing: UAW strike; Birmingham church bombing anniversary; NPR news quiz
item.description: This morning's newsletter incorrectly said the CDC recommends everyone 6 years and older get the new COVID-19 vaccine. In fact, it's everyone 6 months and older.

item.title: Exxon minimized climate change internally after conceding that fossil fuels cause it
item.description: An earlier version of this story incorrectly said that Exxon recently bought a company called Denbury. That acquisition has not been completed.

item.title: A corruption trial revealed a #MeToo ethics entanglement for a top Biden adviser
item.description: NPR updated this story to more clearly define the differences between the Time's Up Legal Defense Fund, Time's Up Now and the Time's Up Foundation.

item.title: 'NY Times' reporter details the struggle within the military to modernize its forces
item.description: The audio of this interview incorrectly refers to Haley Barbour as a former governor of Louisiana. He is a former governor of Mississippi.
